values: No new chapter because instead I got caught up in Photoshop.  What's a fantasy world without the map? All place names subject to change whenever my imagination activates. Trade City is where everyone met, a place that lies sort of outside of all the kingdoms. It's a bit lawless, but is no use from a military standpoint so it gets left alone.  It's the best place to find adventurers and mercenaries. Justin and Joey are from Central Kingdom, not the capital but the city up in the Northeastern tip of the country. That kingdom is the most Eurpean, with a solid medieval culture.  They consider themselves to be the only truly civilized people, though the rest would disagree.  The political structure is fuedal, with a king and powerful nobles who quarrel constantly among themselves. Brian and Kevin are from the deep forest of the Western Lands, though Brian has settled in Trade City.  The population there is sparse, with only a few cities.  Each small settlement governs itself and sends a representative to the high council in the capital.  Because of the desert they have little quarrel with the South, and they have always been somewhat beneath the notice of Central.  But they do have trouble with the immigrants from the north, and so fight many small skirmishes on that front. Howard and Christopher are from the islands (not the same isalnds as each other), which tend to be transfered between the Eastern and Central Kingdoms every few generations, either by war or by treaty.  The individual islands are really small city-states, and play the two larger kingdoms against each other.  They are the traders of the five kingdoms, as well as the entertainers.  The people of the islands are physically different from the mainlanders, much shorter and somewhat swarthy.  each islad, and indeed each individual Isalder, is always out for their own profit and advancement. Lance and Nikolas are from the Southern Lands, Nikolas from the sea port in the Southwest and Lance from a nomadic tribe that wanders the plains.  This land is ruled by many princes, and they are constantly at war with one another.  When the Eastern Overlords began to lose their hold a hundred years ago, the princes worked together to create an army to free themselves.  Though that union did not last, the concpet of an elite fighting force trained in a (supposedly) nuetral city has remained to this day.  Only the most promising young men are sent to be trained as elite fighters in the desert city (where the rivers fork) and that's where out boys met.  These fighters take a vow that if the Southern Lands are ever again threatened by another kingdom they will leave whatever commander they currently follow and return to defend their homeland.  Most of the younger generation thinks this about as likely as the second coming in our world. The eastern kingdom has a history of small city states that were forged together into a strong empire many generations ago.  For a short time they held all the islands and most of the Southern Lands, but they were beaten back by the Central Kingdom about a hundred years ago, and basically shut down all contact with everyone else.  Except of course the Islands, which they still scheme to retake. No one else knows much about their culture or way of life these days. The northern lands were once a thriving kingdom, but the climate changed about three hundred years ago and most of the population migrated south.  The remaining political structure is a remanant of past glories, caught up in preserving old customs.  Every generation they are fewer in number, mostly because so many attempt to head into the Western Lands for a better life.

"You guys awake?" came Joey's voice, a bit too loud for the hour. "No!" replied Justin. Chris's high laughter rang out as someone tried the door handle. "C'mon, open up." 
"No, shut up, you'll wake up Lance" replied Justin. Lance put a hand over his mouth to stifle his laugh.

Lance shook his head as he pulled out the pancake mix. He measured out the ingrdients, then turned on the electric skillet. He poured out several pancakes and then went back to his room, opening the door and calling, "Your turn for the shower, JuJu." 
He returned to the kitchen and turned the pancakes, then pulled out the syrup and butter from the tiny refridgerator and set them on the table in front of Chris, who had retrieved the newspaper from the hallway.
